issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

assignee.name: knutanders
assignee.emailAddress: knut dot hatlen at oracle dot com

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
With my last "svn up " I see the following failure when I run with Java
7 (not with 6), sane classes or sane jars (I didn't test insane), on
Solaris 11.

It seems the recent checkin 1167226 introduced this failure.

Caveat, there are knows issues with the first Java 7 release. If it
looks mysterious, we could wait till the update release is available to
track this down..

creator.name: dagw
creator.emailAddress: dag dot wanvik at oracle dot com

reporter.name: dagw
reporter.emailAddress: dag dot wanvik at oracle dot com

author.name: dagw
author.emailAddress: dag dot wanvik at oracle dot com

comments.body: Interestingly, if I remove the java -client flag, the test passes. This suggests this may not be a Derby bug.

updateAuthor.name: dagw
updateAuthor.emailAddress: dag dot wanvik at oracle dot com

author.name: knutanders
author.emailAddress: knut dot hatlen at oracle dot com

comments.body: This happens if one of the test cases testAlterTablePrivilegesIntace() or testAlterTableWithPrivileges() is executed before testGrantRevokeDDL(), and it probably only works because on Java 6 and earlier the test cases are usually (but not always) executed in the order in which they appear in the source. On Java 7, the order is less predictable.

updateAuthor.name: knutanders
updateAuthor.emailAddress: knut dot hatlen at oracle dot com

author.name: knutanders
author.emailAddress: knut dot hatlen at oracle dot com

comments.body: The attached patch makes the test cases testAlterTablePrivilegesIntace() and testAlterTableWithPrivileges() drop the schemas USER1 and USER2 when they're done, so that these schemas don't unexpectedly turn up in queries executed by the other test cases.

updateAuthor.name: knutanders
updateAuthor.emailAddress: knut dot hatlen at oracle dot com

author.name: knutanders
author.emailAddress: knut dot hatlen at oracle dot com

updateAuthor.name: knutanders
updateAuthor.emailAddress: knut dot hatlen at oracle dot com

author.emailAddress: dag dot wanvik at oracle dot com

updateAuthor.emailAddress: dag dot wanvik at oracle dot com

author.name: myrna
author.emailAddress: m dot v dot lunteren at gmail dot com

comments.body: Mamta just backported the changes of revision 1167226, so I assume these changes now need to be backported too...

updateAuthor.name: myrna
updateAuthor.emailAddress: m dot v dot lunteren at gmail dot com

author.name: myrna
author.emailAddress: m dot v dot lunteren at gmail dot com

comments.body:
I couldn't reproduce the problem with the version of jdk 1.7 on my system
(Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 1.7.0-b147)), but I backported the change and the test still passes.
committed with revision 1179724 to 10.8 branch.

updateAuthor.name: myrna
updateAuthor.emailAddress: m dot v dot lunteren at gmail dot com

comments.body: Thanks for backporting this to 10.8,Myrna. You probably didn't run into it before the backport because the order in which tests get picked from the junit test are unpredictable.
